<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The aqueous solution reaction of chelidamic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM), succinic acid, CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the air at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, along with little of ammonia added dropwise, gave rise to colorless crystals {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(CAM)(HCAM)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), which presents an interesting (4,6)-connected 3D structure. Notably, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the third homonuclear 3D framework based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand, which acts as two different <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-bridges in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and was abbreviated to HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, respectively, in writing molecular formula of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits strong blue photoluminescence at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The aqueous solution reaction of chelidamic acid (H3CAM), succinic acid, CdCl2⋅2.5H2O in the air at 50°C, along with little of ammonia added dropwise, gave rise to colorless crystals {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7⋅1.5H2O}n (1), which presents an interesting (4,6)-connected 3D structure. Notably, 1 is the third homonuclear 3D framework based on H3CAM ligand, which acts as two different μ 4/μ 5-bridges in 1 and was abbreviated to HCAM2- and CAM3-, respectively, in writing molecular formula of 1. Polymer 1 exhibits strong blue photoluminescence at room temperature.

Graphical abstract

The third homonuclear 3D framework {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7 ⋅1.5H2O}n (1) based on chelidamic acid, which presents two different μ 4/μ 5 coordination modes in 1 and is abbreviated to HCAM2- and CAM3-, respectively, in writing molecular formula. Polymer 1 adopts an unusual (4,6)-connected 3D topology with the Schläfli symbol (44.62)(44.610.8)2.

Highlights

   ⋅ Polymer 1 is the third homonuclear 3D framework with chelidamic acid.   ⋅ The chelidamic acid in 1 exhibits two different coordination modes.   ⋅ Polymer 1 presents a novel binodal (4,6)-connected 3D topology (44.62)(44.610.8)2.   ⋅ Polymer 1 can act as good candidates for efficient blue emission materials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the third homonuclear 3D framework with chelidamic acid.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The chelidamic acid in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits two different coordination modes.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a novel binodal (4,6)-connected 3D topology (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can act as good candidates for efficient blue emission materials.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The usage of multidentate organic ligands in constructing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with predictable structures and novel properties is an area of chemistry which has received ever-increasing attention for decades . The assembly of MOFs based on the multichelating chelidamic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM) ligand has been of great attraction due to its significant role in designing molecules and preparation of functional material . The chelidamic acid ligand possesses six potential binding centers (five O from two carboxylate and one hydroxy and one N from pyridyl) and can serve as a class of excellent multidentate ligands exhibiting flexible coordination fashions. In recent years, a large number of complexes containing H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand have been reported. The examples for the Zn, Mn, Cu, V, Gd, Nd, Dy, Tb, Pr and Er complexes exhibit 2D structures with uninodal network topologies , the other known complexes with H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligands are discrete or 1D structures . However, up to now, few examples are involved in the 3D framework . Further studies on multidimensional MOFs constructed from H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligands are of fundamental importance. Notably, the first 3D examples for transition metal Cu or rare earth metal La among the metal-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM complexes have been obtained and studied respectively in our lab .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Polymer 1 is the third homonuclear 3D framework with chelidamic acid.

The chelidamic acid in 1 exhibits two different coordination modes.

Polymer 1 presents a novel binodal (4,6)-connected 3D topology (44.62)(44.610.8)2.

Polymer 1 can act as good candidates for efficient blue emission materials.

The usage of multidentate organic ligands in constructing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with predictable structures and novel properties is an area of chemistry which has received ever-increasing attention for decades . The assembly of MOFs based on the multichelating chelidamic acid (H3CAM) ligand has been of great attraction due to its significant role in designing molecules and preparation of functional material . The chelidamic acid ligand possesses six potential binding centers (five O from two carboxylate and one hydroxy and one N from pyridyl) and can serve as a class of excellent multidentate ligands exhibiting flexible coordination fashions. In recent years, a large number of complexes containing H3CAM ligand have been reported. The examples for the Zn, Mn, Cu, V, Gd, Nd, Dy, Tb, Pr and Er complexes exhibit 2D structures with uninodal network topologies , the other known complexes with H3CAM ligands are discrete or 1D structures . However, up to now, few examples are involved in the 3D framework . Further studies on multidimensional MOFs constructed from H3CAM ligands are of fundamental importance. Notably, the first 3D examples for transition metal Cu or rare earth metal La among the metal-H3CAM complexes have been obtained and studied respectively in our lab .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this context and as an extension of our research, a new 3D Cd(II) coordination polymer {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(CAM)(HCAM)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>chelidamic acid) was obtained successfully by means of the solution reaction in the air at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. To the best of our knowledge, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the third homonuclear 3D framework constructed by H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand, which presents an interesting 3D (4,6)-connected framework . The photoluminescent property for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been studied, which displays strong blue emissions with large blue shift of 57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm compared with the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context and as an extension of our research, a new 3D Cd(II) coordination polymer {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7⋅1.5H2O}n (1) (H3CAM=chelidamic acid) was obtained successfully by means of the solution reaction in the air at 50°C. To the best of our knowledge, 1 is the third homonuclear 3D framework constructed by H3CAM ligand, which presents an interesting 3D (4,6)-connected framework . The photoluminescent property for 1 has been studied, which displays strong blue emissions with large blue shift of 57nm compared with the free H3CAM ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">As-synthesized, aqueous solution reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM, succinic acid, CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the air at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, along with little of ammonia added dropwise under the pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7–8, gave rise to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
. The initial purpose is to synthesize a multidimensional MOF with mixed ligands of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM and succinic acid. But only colorless prismatic crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained over a period of 7 d. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is insoluble in water and common solvents. The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was shown in Fig. S1. The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at room temperature agrees well with the simulated one based on the single-crystal X-ray data (Fig. S2), indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is in a pure phase.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As-synthesized, aqueous solution reaction of H3CAM, succinic acid, CdCl2⋅2.5H2O in the air at 50°C, along with little of ammonia added dropwise under the pH=7-8, gave rise to 1 . The initial purpose is to synthesize a multidimensional MOF with mixed ligands of H3CAM and succinic acid. But only colorless prismatic crystals of 1 were obtained over a period of 7 d. Polymer 1 is insoluble in water and common solvents. The IR spectrum of 1 was shown in Fig. S1. The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 at room temperature agrees well with the simulated one based on the single-crystal X-ray data (Fig. S2), indicating that 1 is in a pure phase.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">A single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains two and half Cd(II) atoms (Cd1, Cd2 and 1/2Cd3, respectively), two chelidamic acid ligands, seven coordinated waters, one and half uncoordinated water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are both seven-coordinated with a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry made up of one nitrogen atom and six oxygen atoms (N1, O1, O4, O15, O1D, O3W and O4W for Cd1 coordinated by three different chelidamic acid ligands, and N2, O11A, O14A, O11, O5W, O6W and O7W for Cd2 coordinated by two different chelidamic acid ligands), while Cd3 is six-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry made up of six oxygen atoms (O3, O13, O2C, O12B, O1W and O2W) from four different chelidamic acid ligands and two coordinated water molecules. The Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances range from 2.2477(18) to 2.5203(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with the average distance of 2.362(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. And the Cd1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N1 and Cd2<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N2B bond distances are 2.280(2) and 2.284(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (Table S1), respectively. The Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond distances all lie in the normal range of those reported Cd complexes with chelidamic acid in the literature . Notably, there exists two different chelidamic acid ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, one of which exhibits the mode of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O1,N1,O4:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O1:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O2:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O3 and the other adopts the mode of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O11,N2,O14:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O11:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O12:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O13:<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>O15. Obviously, the difference between them lies in hydroxyl group from the chelidamic acid for the latter involved in bridging Cd(II) centers. Accordingly, they are abbreviated to HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, respectively, in writing molecular formula of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Therefore, as shown in , Cd1 is coordinated by two HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and one CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, Cd2 is coordinated by two CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, while Cd3 is coordinated by two HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and two CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands. Interestingly, two Cd1 centers are double bridged by two O atoms (O1 and O1D) from two HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands to form a centrosymmetric binuclear unit A of [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HCAM<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. Similarly, two Cd2 centers are double bridged by O11 and O11A atoms from two CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands to form another centrosymmetric binuclear unit B of [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CAM<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. Each binuclear unit A or B is linked by four Cd3 centers via the carboxylate O from the chelidamic acid. And each Cd3 center is connected by two binuclear units A and two binuclear units B. Therefore, binuclear units (A or B) and Cd3 center can be considered as a four-connected node, which forms an undulating (4,4)-connected topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Furthermore, each Cd1 center in binuclear unit A is linked by one hydroxyl group from binuclear unit B in neighboring layer. Thus, the binuclear units A and B between adjacent layers are connected to each other through the hydroxyl groups, affording the final 3D metal-organic framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). In simple terms, all Cd(II) centers are bridged by carboxylate O atoms to form 2D layers, which are further connected by hydroxyl O atoms to generate the 3D framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two and half Cd(II) atoms (Cd1, Cd2 and 1/2Cd3, respectively), two chelidamic acid ligands, seven coordinated waters, one and half uncoordinated water molecules ( ). The Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are both seven-coordinated with a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry made up of one nitrogen atom and six oxygen atoms (N1, O1, O4, O15, O1D, O3W and O4W for Cd1 coordinated by three different chelidamic acid ligands, and N2, O11A, O14A, O11, O5W, O6W and O7W for Cd2 coordinated by two different chelidamic acid ligands), while Cd3 is six-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry made up of six oxygen atoms (O3, O13, O2C, O12B, O1W and O2W) from four different chelidamic acid ligands and two coordinated water molecules. The CdO bond distances range from 2.2477(18) to 2.5203(19)Å with the average distance of 2.362(2)Å. And the Cd1N1 and Cd2N2B bond distances are 2.280(2) and 2.284(2)Å (Table S1), respectively. The CdO and CdN bond distances all lie in the normal range of those reported Cd complexes with chelidamic acid in the literature . Notably, there exists two different chelidamic acid ligands in 1, one of which exhibits the mode of μ 4-κO1,N1,O4:κO1:κO2:κO3 and the other adopts the mode of μ 5-κO11,N2,O14:κO11:κO12:κO13:κO15. Obviously, the difference between them lies in hydroxyl group from the chelidamic acid for the latter involved in bridging Cd(II) centers. Accordingly, they are abbreviated to HCAM2- and CAM3-, respectively, in writing molecular formula of 1. Therefore, as shown in , Cd1 is coordinated by two HCAM2- and one CAM3- ligands, Cd2 is coordinated by two CAM3- ligands, while Cd3 is coordinated by two HCAM2- and two CAM3- ligands. Interestingly, two Cd1 centers are double bridged by two O atoms (O1 and O1D) from two HCAM2- ligands to form a centrosymmetric binuclear unit A of [Cd2(HCAM2-)2]. Similarly, two Cd2 centers are double bridged by O11 and O11A atoms from two CAM3- ligands to form another centrosymmetric binuclear unit B of [Cd2(CAM3-)2]. Each binuclear unit A or B is linked by four Cd3 centers via the carboxylate O from the chelidamic acid. And each Cd3 center is connected by two binuclear units A and two binuclear units B. Therefore, binuclear units (A or B) and Cd3 center can be considered as a four-connected node, which forms an undulating (4,4)-connected topology ( ). Furthermore, each Cd1 center in binuclear unit A is linked by one hydroxyl group from binuclear unit B in neighboring layer. Thus, the binuclear units A and B between adjacent layers are connected to each other through the hydroxyl groups, affording the final 3D metal-organic framework of 1 ( ). In simple terms, all Cd(II) centers are bridged by carboxylate O atoms to form 2D layers, which are further connected by hydroxyl O atoms to generate the 3D framework of 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A better insight into the 3D network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be achieved by application of a topological approach. When binuclear units A and B are treated as six-connected nodes and Cd3 centers are treated as four-connected nodes, as mentioned above, the architecture of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be reduced to a binodal structure with six-connected (A or B units) and four-connected (Cd3 centers) nodes, adopting an interesting 3D topology with the Schläfli symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with the 1:2 ratio of 4-connected and 6-connected node (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Noteworthily, it is different from the fsc topology with the Schläfli symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>.8) reported in the literature . Among those reported in the literature, all nodes in the (4,4)-connected layers are coplanar, in contrast to the undulating (4,4)-connected layers with the wave crests coinciding with the troughs of adjacent layers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also completely different from the rarely reported (4,6)-connected MOFs with (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>.8), (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), (3.4.5<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)(3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4.5<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) and (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>) topologies . Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a new binodal (4,6)-connected 3D network topology. The formations of these structures show a good example that different connectivity between the building units can result in different structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A better insight into the 3D network of 1 can be achieved by application of a topological approach. When binuclear units A and B are treated as six-connected nodes and Cd3 centers are treated as four-connected nodes, as mentioned above, the architecture of 1 can be reduced to a binodal structure with six-connected (A or B units) and four-connected (Cd3 centers) nodes, adopting an interesting 3D topology with the Schläfli symbol (44.62)(44.610.8)2 with the 1:2 ratio of 4-connected and 6-connected node ( ). Noteworthily, it is different from the fsc topology with the Schläfli symbol (44.62)(44.610.8) reported in the literature . Among those reported in the literature, all nodes in the (4,4)-connected layers are coplanar, in contrast to the undulating (4,4)-connected layers with the wave crests coinciding with the troughs of adjacent layers in 1. The structure of 1 is also completely different from the rarely reported (4,6)-connected MOFs with (44.62)2(44.610.8), (44.62)(48.66.8)(42.52.62)(42.56.64.73), (3.4.54)(32.4.56.66) and (44.62)(46.69) topologies . Polymer 1 presents a new binodal (4,6)-connected 3D network topology. The formations of these structures show a good example that different connectivity between the building units can result in different structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Notably, unlike the mostly known complexes with chelidamic acid ligand , in which the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM acts as a <ce:italic>mono</ce:italic>-, <ce:italic>bi</ce:italic>-, or tridentate ligand to form 0D, 1D, or 2D structures, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> acts as a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-bridge to link the Cd(II) centers into a novel homonuclear 3D structure, which is the third example for the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand. Obviously, the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the 3D molecular frameworks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. To our best knowledge, there are only four reported complexes (Gd, Er, Cu, La) , in which the hydroxyl group from H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand coordinated with metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Notably, unlike the mostly known complexes with chelidamic acid ligand , in which the H3CAM acts as a mono-, bi-, or tridentate ligand to form 0D, 1D, or 2D structures, the H3CAM ligand in 1 acts as a μ 4/μ 5-bridge to link the Cd(II) centers into a novel homonuclear 3D structure, which is the third example for the H3CAM ligand. Obviously, the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the 3D molecular frameworks of 1. To our best knowledge, there are only four reported complexes (Gd, Er, Cu, La) , in which the hydroxyl group from H3CAM ligand coordinated with metal ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">By comparing <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with our previously reported 3D La/Cu polymers , the organic H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> take two different coordination modes from that in La/Cu polymers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>), and there is only one crystallographic independent H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand in La/Cu polymers. On the other hand, the asymmetric unit in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains three kinds of Cd(II) atoms (seven-coordinated Cd1/Cd2 and six-coordinated Cd3, respectively), while there exist two kinds of Cu(II) atoms (four-coordinated Cu1 and six-coordinated Cu2) in the Cu polymer and only one nine-coordinated La(III) atom for the La polymer. Furthermore, polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 space group, while La/Cu polymer crystallizes monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> and orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pnna</ce:italic> space group, respectively. The distinct coordination modes of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligands and coordination environment around the metal centers, along with the different space group, are responsible for variable 3D polymeric frameworks. Interestingly, La/Cu polymers show (3,6)-connected topology with symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.10<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) and (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>.10), respectively, but polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents the (4,6)-connected (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> topology based on their respective simplification principle.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By comparing 1 with our previously reported 3D La/Cu polymers , the organic H3CAM ligands in 1 take two different coordination modes from that in La/Cu polymers ( ), and there is only one crystallographic independent H3CAM ligand in La/Cu polymers. On the other hand, the asymmetric unit in 1 contains three kinds of Cd(II) atoms (seven-coordinated Cd1/Cd2 and six-coordinated Cd3, respectively), while there exist two kinds of Cu(II) atoms (four-coordinated Cu1 and six-coordinated Cu2) in the Cu polymer and only one nine-coordinated La(III) atom for the La polymer. Furthermore, polymer 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P-1 space group, while La/Cu polymer crystallizes monoclinic C2/c and orthorhombic Pnna space group, respectively. The distinct coordination modes of H3CAM ligands and coordination environment around the metal centers, along with the different space group, are responsible for variable 3D polymeric frameworks. Interestingly, La/Cu polymers show (3,6)-connected topology with symbol (42.6)2(44.62.87.102) and (42.6)2(44.62.88.10), respectively, but polymer 1 presents the (4,6)-connected (44.62)(44.610.8)2 topology based on their respective simplification principle.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand at room temperature were given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits blue luminescence with the maximum emission at 469<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, while the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand exhibits green luminescence with the maximum emission at 526<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Compared to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> results in much higher emission energy with a large blue shift of 57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. This indicates that the emission of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be originated from charge transition between the ligand and the metal ions. The luminescent properties show that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be a good blue light-emitted material. The diffuse reflectance spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>eV (Fig. S3, Supporting Information).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of 1 and the free H3CAM ligand at room temperature were given in  . Complex 1 exhibits blue luminescence with the maximum emission at 469nm upon excitation at 370nm, while the free H3CAM ligand exhibits green luminescence with the maximum emission at 526nm upon excitation at 365nm. Compared to the free H3CAM ligand, complex 1 results in much higher emission energy with a large blue shift of 57nm. This indicates that the emission of 1 may be originated from charge transition between the ligand and the metal ions. The luminescent properties show that 1 may be a good blue light-emitted material. The diffuse reflectance spectra of 1 reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.45eV (Fig. S3, Supporting Information).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In summary, we have obtained the third new 3D coordination polymer {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(CAM)(HCAM)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand, presenting an interesting (4,6)-connected framework. The structural analyses show that the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the multidimensional MOFs for H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand. Compared with the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CAM ligand, polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a strong blue photoluminescence with large blue shift of 57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have obtained the third new 3D coordination polymer {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7⋅1.5H2O}n (1) based on the H3CAM ligand, presenting an interesting (4,6)-connected framework. The structural analyses show that the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the multidimensional MOFs for H3CAM ligand. Compared with the free H3CAM ligand, polymer 1 displays a strong blue photoluminescence with large blue shift of 57nm.

<ce:simple-para id="sp4050" view="all">All chemicals were commercially available sources of analytical grade and used without further purification. The elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. The FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. Optical diffuse reflectance spectra were measured on a PE Lambda 900UV-vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and the BaSO4 plate was used as the reference. Photoluminescent analysis was performed on an Edinburgh EI920 fluorescence spectrometer with a 450-W Xe lamp and a R928P PMT detector. A 399-nm high-pass filter was applied when performing PL determinations. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Miniflex II diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.540598<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV and 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA in the range of 5°<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≤<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≤<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>50°. The simulated patterns were derived from the Mercury Version 1.4 software (<ce:inter-ref id="ir0500" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/mercury/" xlink:type="simple">http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/mercury/</ce:inter-ref>). Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out by a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo K radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Siemens SAINT software was used for data reduction. The intensity data sets were collected with the  scan technique and corrected for Lp effects.</ce:simple-para>

Supplementary material

   Supplementary material   Materials and instruments  All chemicals were commercially available sources of analytical grade and used without further purification. The elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. The FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000-400cm-1. Optical diffuse reflectance spectra were measured on a PE Lambda 900UV-vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere at 293K, and the BaSO4 plate was used as the reference. Photoluminescent analysis was performed on an Edinburgh EI920 fluorescence spectrometer with a 450-W Xe lamp and a R928P PMT detector. A 399-nm high-pass filter was applied when performing PL determinations. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Miniflex II diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.540598Å) at 40kV and 40mA in the range of 5°≤2≤50°. The simulated patterns were derived from the Mercury Version 1.4 software (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/mercury/). Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out by a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo K radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 293(2)K. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Siemens SAINT software was used for data reduction. The intensity data sets were collected with the  scan technique and corrected for Lp effects.  Table S1 Selected bond lengths (Å) for 1 a.  Figure S1 The FT-IR spectra of 1.  Figure S2 The experimental and simulated PXRD patterns of 1 at room temperature.  Figure S3 The diffuse reflectance spectrum of 1.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of 1 and the free H3CAM ligand at room temperature were given in  . Complex 1 exhibits blue luminescence with the maximum emission at 469nm upon excitation at 370nm, while the free H3CAM ligand exhibits green luminescence with the maximum emission at 526nm upon excitation at 365nm. Compared to the free H3CAM ligand, complex 1 results in much higher emission energy with a large blue shift of 57nm. This indicates that the emission of 1 may be originated from charge transition between the ligand and the metal ions. The luminescent properties show that 1 may be a good blue light-emitted material. The diffuse reflectance spectra of 1 reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.45eV (Fig. S3, Supporting Information).

In summary, we have obtained the third new 3D coordination polymer {Cd2.5(CAM)(HCAM)(H2O)7⋅1.5H2O}n (1) based on the H3CAM ligand, presenting an interesting (4,6)-connected framework. The structural analyses show that the coordination of hydroxyl group with metal centers plays an important role in governing the multidimensional MOFs for H3CAM ligand. Compared with the free H3CAM ligand, polymer 1 displays a strong blue photoluminescence with large blue shift of 57nm.

Crystal data for 1: C28H44N4O37Cd5, Mr =1590.67, colorless crystal, triclinic, space group P-1, a =10.2240(17)Å, b =11.2172(18)Å, c =11.3302(19)Å, α =69.059(2), β =76.930(2), γ =88.666(2) º, V =1179.8(3)Å3, Z =1, T =293(2)K, D calcd. =2.239gcm-3, μ =2.334mm-1, R (wR)=0.0413 (0.1161) and GOF=1.046 for 4290 reflections with I >2.00 σ(I). The crystal structure of 1 was solved by direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTL version 5 package of crystallographic software and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. Non-hydrogen atoms were located by difference Fourier maps and subjected to anisotropic refinement. All hydrogen atoms of carbon atoms were calculated in idealized positions and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules were located in difference Fourier syntheses and refined with O-H distances restrained to a target value of 0.85Å and Uiso (H)=1.5Ueq (O), and hydrogen atoms of lattice water molecules were not included for 1.
